metadata.title: Glycosyltransferases promote development and prevent promiscuous cell

abstract.text: The mechanisms underlying multicellular development in the animal stem lineage may 25 be reconstructed through the study of choanoflagellates, the closest living relatives of 26 animals. To determine the genetic underpinnings of multicellularity in the emerging 27 model choanoflagellate S. rosetta, we performed a screen for mutants with defects in 28 multicellular rosette development. In two of the mutants, Jumble and Couscous, single 29 cells failed to develop into orderly rosettes but instead aggregated promiscuously into 30 amorphous clumps of cells. Both mutants mapped to lesions in genes encoding 31 glycosyltransferases and the mutations perturbed glycosylation patterns in the 32 extracellular matrix (ECM). In animals, glycosyltransferases transfer activated sugars to 33 donor molecules and thereby sculpt the polysaccharide-rich ECM, regulate integrin and 34 cadherin activity, and, when disrupted, contribute to tumorigenesis. The finding that 35 glycosyltransferases promote proper rosette development and prevent cell aggregation 36 in S. rosetta suggests a pre-metazoan role for glycosyltransferases in regulating 37 development and preventing abnormal tumor-like multicellularity.

body_text.text: The evolution of multicellular eukaryotes from their single-celled ancestors was a 42 major transition in evolutionary history and allowed for the subsequent origin and 43 diversification of complex macroscopic life (Leigh et al., 1995) . However, despite the 44 centrality of multicellularity to the origin and diversification of animals, little is known 45 about the genetic and developmental mechanisms that precipitated the transition to 46 multicellularity in the animal stem lineage. Against a background of sequence 163 variants that did not segregate perfectly with the Rosetteless phenotype, five unlinked 164 single nucleotide variants (SNVs) and insertions/deletions (INDELs) were found to 165 perfectly segregate with the phenotype (Table S2 ). Four of these detected sequence 166 variants likely had spurious correlations with the phenotype resulting from relatively low 167 sequencing coverage at those variants (>0.25X coverage of the entire genome) ( Table  168 S2). In contrast, the remaining SNV was detected in a well-assembled portion of the 169 genome at a sequencing depth approaching the average coverage of the entire 170 genome. The perfectly segregating SNV, at position 427,804 on supercontig 8, was 171 identical to the causative mutation identified in Levin et al., 2014 (Table S2) . Thus, a 172 method based on pooling F1 haploid mutants, identifying sequence variants that 173 perfectly segregated with the phenotype, and masking those SNVs/INDELs that were 174 detected with >0.25X coverage of the total genome was effective for correctly 175 pinpointing the causal mutation for Rosetteless (Figure 2-figure supplement 1 Jumble that segregated perfectly with both the clumping and rosette defects. Moreover, in contrast with the structural stability and shear 116 resistance of wild type rosettes (Figure 1A) (Levin et al., 2014), the cell clumps formed 117 by Class C mutants were sensitive to shear and separated into solitary cells upon 118 pipetting or vortexing the culture (Figure 1A). 119 Following exposure to shear, we observed that mutant cells re-aggregated into 120 new clumps within minutes, while wild type cells never formed clumps (Figure 1C, D; 121 rare cell doublets were likely due to recent cell divisions). Within 30 minutes after 122 disruption by shear force, cell clumps as large as 75, 55, 32, and 23 cells formed in 123 Couscous, Soapsuds, Seafoam, and Jumble mutant cultures, respectively. The cell 124 aggregation was not strain-specific, as unlabeled Jumble and Couscous mutant cells 125 adhered to wild type cells identified by their expression of cytoplasmic mWasabi (Figure 126

FIGREF1.text: genetic mapping in S. rosetta through bulk segregant analysis 135 We next set out to identify the causative mutation(s) underlying the clumping and 136 rosette defect phenotypes in each of these mutants. In the Levin et al. 2014 study, the 137 Rosetteless mutant was crossed to a phenotypically wild type Mapping Strain 138 (previously called Isolate B in Levin et al., 2014) and relied on genotyping of haploid F1s 139 at 60 PCR-verified genetic markers that differed between the Rosetteless mutant and 140 the Mapping Strain (Levin et al., 2014). The 60 markers were distributed unevenly 141 across the 55 Mb genome and proved to be insufficient for mapping the Class C 142 mutants for this study. Compounding the problem, the low level of sequence 143 polymorphism among S. rosetta laboratory strains and abundance of repetitive 144 sequences in the draft genome assembly (Fairclough et al., 2013; Levin et al., 2014) 145 made it difficult to identify and validate additional genetic markers, while genotyping at 146 individual markers proved labor intensive and costly. 147 To overcome these barriers, we modified bulk segregation methods developed in 148 other systems (Doitsidou et al., 2010; Leshchiner et al., 2012; Lister et al., 2009; 149 Pomraning et al., 2011; Schneeberger et al., 2009; Voz et al., 2012; Wenger et al., 150 2010) for use in S. rosetta. FIGREF3.text: 228 of the Jumble mutant by the wild type jumble allele, albeit in a subset of the population, 229 provided further confirmation that the jumble lw1 mutation causes the cell clumping and 230 rosette defect phenotypes. The fact that the transfection experiment did not allow all 231 cells to develop into rosettes may be due to any number of reasons, including 232 incomplete selection against untransfected cells, differences in transgene expression 233 levels in different transfected cells, and the possibility that the mTFP tag reduces or 234 otherwise changes the activity of the Jumble protein. 235 We next sought to determine the function and phylogenetic distribution of the 236 jumble gene. BLAST searches uncovered unannotated jumble homologs in nine other 237 choanoflagellates (Figure 2-figure supplement 2A) and in fungi, but none in animals. 238 The choanoflagellate homologs of jumble were detected in the transcriptomes of 239 species representing each of the three major choanoflagellate clades (Richter et al., 240 2018), suggesting that jumble evolved before the origin and diversification of 241 choanoflagellates. Although Interpro (Finn et al., 2017) and Pfam (Finn et al., 2016) did 242 not reveal any known protein domains in Jumble, the NCBI Conserved Domain Search 243 (Marchler-Bauer et al., 2017) predicted a glycosyltransferase domain with low 244

FIGREF4.text: Jumble lw1 disrupts a predicted alpha helix, which we hypothesize would 251 prevent proper folding of the Jumble protein (Figure 2A). 252Glycosyltransferases play essential roles in animal development(Sawaguchi et  253   al., 2017;Zhang et al., 2008) and cell adhesion(Müller et al., 1979;Stratford, 1992).254 Their biochemical functions include transferring an activated nucleotide sugar, also 255 called a glycosyl donor, to lipid, protein, or carbohydrate acceptors (Lairson et al., 256 2008). Target acceptors in animals include key signaling and adhesion proteins such as 257 integrins and cadherins, whose activities are regulated by N-and O-linked 258 polysaccharide modifications, also referred to as N-and O-linked glycans (Larsen et al., 259 2017; Zhao et al., 2008). Notably, many well-characterized glycosyltransferases act in 260 the Golgi apparatus, where they glycosylate molecules that are trafficked through the 261 secretory system (El-Battari, 2006; Tu and Banfield, 2010). To investigate the 262 localization of Jumble, we transfected wild type cells with a jumble-mWasabi gene 263 fusion transcribed under the control of the S. rosetta efl promoter. Jumble-mWasabi 264 protein localized to the apical pole of the cell body near the base of the flagellum. Based 265 on comparisons with transmission electron micrographs of S. rosetta and other 266 choanoflagellates, Jumble-mWasabi localization corresponds to the location of the Golgi 267 apparatus, for which there is not yet a fluorescent marker in S. rosetta (Figure 2E,G; 268

FIGREF5.text: figure supplement 3A)(Leadbeater, 2015). In contrast, Jumble lw1 -mWasabi,Booth et al., 2018). The ER localization of Jumble lw1 is consistent with the hypothesis 272 that the missense mutation disrupts proper protein folding as often misfolded proteins 273 are retained in the ER and targeted for degradation(Kopito, 1997). The failure of the 274 Jumble lw1 protein to localize properly at the Golgi apparatus strongly suggests a loss of 275 function. 276 277Couscous maps to a lesion in a predicted mannosyltransferase 278We followed a similar strategy to map the genetic lesion(s) underlying the 279Couscous mutant phenotype. Using the bulk segregant approach on F1 mutant 280 offspring from a Couscous ´ Mapping Strain cross, we identified eight sequence 281 variants that segregated perfectly with the clumping and rosette defect phenotypes, of 282 which only one -a single nucleotide deletion at position 462,534 on supercontig 22 -283 had sequencing coverage at least 0.25X of the average sequence coverage of the rest 284 of the genome (Figure 3A; Table S4). The tight linkage of the deletion to both the 285 clumping and rosette defect phenotypes was further confirmed by genotyping the 286 sequence variant in F2 mutants resulting from backcrosses of F1 mutants to the 287 Mapping Strain (Figure 3B). Given the tight linkage, we infer that the deletion at position 288 462,534 on supercontig 22 causes both clumping and the disruption of rosette 289 development in Couscous mutant cells. 290 The single nucleotide deletion at position 462,534 on supercontig 22 sits in a 291 four-exon gene, hereafter called couscous (GenBank accession EGD77026/ NCBI 292 ). The mutation causes a predicted frameshift leading to an 293 early stop codon in the mutant protein, Couscous lw1 (Figure 3A). As with the Jumble 294 mutant, we were able to rescue rosette formation in a portion of the population by 295 transfecting cells with either a couscous-mTFP or mTFP-couscous gene fusion under 296 the efl promoter (Figure 3C, D), thereby increasing our confidence in the mapping 297 results. 298 The predicted Couscous amino acid sequence contains a specific type of 299 glycosyltransferase domain, an alpha-mannosyltransferase domain, that transfers 300 activated mannose onto the outer chain of core N-linked polysaccharides and O-linked 301 mannotriose (Strahl-Bolsinger et al., 1999). The predicted mannosyltransferase domain 302 shares 28% and 35% amino acid sequence identity to alpha 1-2 mannosyltransferase 303 (MNN2) proteins in Saccharomyces cerevisiae and Candida albicans, respectively, 304 including the conserved DXD motif found in many families of glycosyltransferases 305 (Wiggins and Munro, 1998) (Figure 3-figure supplement 1A). MNN2 proteins catalyze 306 the addition of the first branch of mannose-containing oligosaccharides found on cell 307

Jacalin also brightly stained the ECM filling the center of 335 rosettes in a pattern reminiscent of the Rosetteless C-type lectin (Levin et al., 2014) 336 (Figure 4A, B'), although the two were not imaged simultaneously because jacalin does 337 after cell fixation and labelled Rosetteless antibodies accumulate strongly in the 338 food vacuoles of live cells. In contrast with wild type cells, the basal patch of jacalin 339 staining was absent or significantly diminished in Couscous and Jumble mutants, both 340 in the presence and absence of RIFs (Figure 4 C-F). Interestingly, the apical patch of 341 jacalin staining in mutant cells appeared similar to wild type cells. This may explain the 342 lack of a clear difference in bands detected with jacalin by western blot between wild 343 type and mutants whole cell lysates (Figure 4-figure supplement 1). 344 The loss of basal jacalin staining indicated that the Jumble and Couscous 345 mutations either disrupt proper trafficking of sugar-modified molecules to the basal pole 346 of cells or alter the glycosylation events themselves. Thus, we examined whether the 347 basal secretion of Rosetteless protein was disrupted in the mutant strains. In both 348 Jumble and Couscous, Rosetteless properly localized to the basal pole, but its 349 expression did not increase nor was it secreted upon treatment with RIFs, as normally 350 occurs in wild type cells (Figure 4-figure supplement 2). Because Rosetteless is 351 required for rosette development, this failure to properly upregulate and secrete 352 Rosetteless might contribute to the rosette defect phenotype in Jumble and Couscous 353 cells. 354 355 DISCUSSION 356Of the 16 rosette defect mutants isolated inLevin et al. 2014 and in this study, 357

A 361 recent study revealed that the bacterium Vibrio fischeri induces S. rosetta to form 362 swarms of cells, visually similar to the mutant clumps, as part of their mating behavior 363(Woznica et al., 2017). However, it seems unlikely that the clumping Class C mutants is 364 related to swarming; the cell fusion and subsequent settling of diploid cells characteristic 365 of V. fischeri-induced mating have not been observed in the class C mutants cultured 366 without V. fischeri. 367For both Jumble and Couscous, the causative mutations mapped to predicted 368 glycosyltransferase genes. Consistent with its role as a glycosyltransferase, Jumble 369 localized to the Golgi apparatus, but Couscous appeared to localize in cytoplasmic 370 puncta and to the cell membrane. We predict that the glycosyltransferase mutations are 371 loss of function alleles, given that transfection of mutant S. rosetta with the wild type 372 alleles was sufficient to complement each of the mutations. While we have not 373 uncovered the target(s) of the glycotransferases or the exact nature of the interplay 374 between the two phenotypes, disruption of the glycocalyx at the basal pole of both 375 Jumble and Couscous mutant cells (Figure 4) hints that the regulation of ECM could 376 play a role in preventing clumping and in promoting proper rosette development. 377 One possible explanation for the clumping phenotype is that jumble and 378 couscous are required to regulate the activity of cell surface adhesion molecules and 379 receptors. Glycosylation regulates the activities of two key adhesion proteins in animals: 380 integrins that regulate ECM adhesion, and cadherins that, among their various roles in 381 cell signaling and animal development, bind other cadherins to form cell-cell adhesions 382 called adherens junctions (Larsen et al., 2017; Zhao et al., 2008). Cadherin activity can 383 -V) whose activity leads to decreased cell adhesion (Carvalho et al., 2016; 387 Granovsky et al., 2000). GnT-V knockdown enhances cell-cell adhesion mediated by E-388 cadherin and the related N-cadherin (Carvalho et al., 2016; Guo et al., 2009). The 389 inactivation of E-cadherin, including through over-or under-expression of GnT-V or 390 GnT-III, is considered to be a hallmark of epithelial cancers (Hirohashi and Kanai, 391 2003). S. rosetta expresses 29 different cadherins (Nichols et al., 2012) and it is 392 possible that mutations to jumble and couscous disrupt regulatory glycosylation of a cell 393 adhesion molecules like cadherins. 394 Another possibility is that jumble and couscous add a protective sugar layer to 395 the cell surface and loss of glycosyltransferase activity reveals underlying sticky 396 surfaces. If jumble and couscous add branches to existed sugar modifications, their loss 397 of function could expose new sugar moieties at the cell surface that act as ligands for 398 lectins that aggregate cells. Lectins mediate cell aggregation in diverse organisms 399 (Colin Hughes, 1992). For example, sponges such as Geodia cydonium can be 400 disaggregated into single cells and then reaggregated through lectin binding of a post-401 translational sugar modification (Müller et al., 1979). In S. cerevisiae, the 402 mannosyltransferase MNN2 adds mannose structures to the cell wall that are 403 recognized by aggregating lectins and MNN2 is required for proper flocculation (Rayner 404 and Munro, 1998; Stratford, 1992). Exposing new sugars on the cell surface in Jumble 405

A prior study showed 411 that only S. rosetta cells recognized with the lectin wheat germ agglutinin (WGA) are 412 competent to form rosettes, which suggests that glycosylation might be necessary for 413 rosette development(Dayel et al., 2011). While WGA staining does not appear to be 414 perturbed in Jumble and Couscous(Table S2), jacalin staining at the basal pole 415 appears severely reduced or abolished compared to wild type. Jacalin staining was 416 enriched in the center of wild type rosettes in a pattern reminiscent of Rosetteless, 417 which is required for rosette development(Levin et al., 2014). Intriguingly, in Jumble 418 and Couscous, Rosetteless localized to the correct pole, but did not become enriched 419 upon rosette induction, indicating that the ECM did not properly mature. Rosetteless has 420 mucin-like Ser/Thr repeats that are predicted sites of heavy glycosylation and two C-421 type lectin domains that would be expected to bind to sugar moieties(Levin et al.,  422   2014). Therefore, it is possible that Rosetteless might be regulated either through direct 423 glycosylation or through the glycosylation of potential binding partners by Jumble and 424Couscous. 425The clumping, rosetteless mutants underscore the differences between cell426 aggregation and a regulated clonal developmental program, such as embryogenesis or 427 rosette development. Aggregation is hypothesized to only be evolutionarily stable if 428 close relatives (Gilbert et al., 2007; Kuzdzal-Fick et al., 2011). Recent efforts 429 to experimentally evolve multicellularity in yeast and the green alga Chlamydomonas 430 reinhardtii have all resulted in isolates that formed clonally and not through aggregation 431 (Herron et al., 2018; Ratcliff et al., 2013, 2012). Although aggregation and clonal 432 multicellularity both rely on cell-cell adhesion and cell signaling, the fact that they are 433 mutually exclusive in S. rosetta and in experimental evolution studies argues against 434 their co-occurrence in the animal stem lineage. 435 436 MATERIALS AND METHODS 437 Media preparation, strains, and cell culture 438 Unenriched artificial seawater (ASW), AK artificial seawater (AK), cereal grass 439 media (CG), and high nutrient (HN) media were prepared as described previously 440 (Booth et al., 2018; Levin et al., 2014; Levin and King, 2013). FIGREF19.text: Model for promiscuous clumping in rosette defective Class C mutants. 1153Wild type S. rosetta has a glycosylated basal patch of ECM (red) as marked by the 1154 lectin jacalin that becomes enriched during the course of rosette formation. The 1155Rosetteless protein, required for rosette formation and speculated to play a structural 1156 role in holding rosettes together, localizes to the same location on the basal pole of cells 1157 and becomes similarly enriched as rosette form. Mutants lack the glycosylated basal 1158 patch of jacalin staining. The altered cell surface could lead to clumping, either through 1159 mis-regulation of cell adhesion molecules or exposure of a normally masked adhesive 1160 cell surface. The same alteration that allows clumping of Class C mutants also prevents 1161 rosette develoment, perhaps by disrupting glycan modification on the Rosetteless 1162 protein or one of its interaction partners.

TABREF0.text: ).Therefore, we used this validated bulk segregant method to map the clumping mutants. 177Mapping crosses were carried out for the four clumping/rosette defect mutants 178 characterized in this study (Seafoam, Soapsuds, Jumble, and Couscous) and all four 179 crosses yielded heterozygous diploids, demonstrating that they were competent to180 mate. As observed in prior studies of S. rosetta mating (Levin et al., 2014; Woznica et 181 al., 2017), the diploid cells each secreted a flask-shaped attachment structure called a 182 theca and were obligately unicellular. Therefore, the heterozygous diploids were not 183 informative about whether the mutations were dominant or recessive as the phenotypes 184 could only be detected in haploid cells. For Seafoam and Soapsuds, we isolated 185 heterozygous diploids, but never recovered F1 offspring with the mutant phenotype 186 (Table 1). The inability to recover haploids with either clumping or rosette defect 187 phenotypes from the Seafoam´Mapping Strain and Soapsuds´Mapping Strain crosses 188 might be explained by any of the following: (1) the clumping/rosette defect phenotypes 189 are polygenic, (2) meiosis defects are associated with the causative mutations, and/or 190 (3) mutant fitness defects allowed wild type progeny to outcompete the mutant progeny. 191 In contrast, heterozygous diploids from crosses of Jumble and Couscous to the 192 Mapping Strain produced F1 haploid progeny with both wild type and mutant 193 phenotypes and thus allowed for the successful mapping of the causative genetic 194 lesions, as detailed below. 195 Jumble maps to a putative glycosyltransferase 197Following the bulk segregant approach, we identified 5 sequence variants in 198
